blocks.text: It is decided Louise is too young for so extensive a trip, so she is deposited with Grandfather and Grandmother Kreider while the rest of the family is away. Here she waves goodbye on Friday evening from in front of Kreiders' home on Cottage Avenue.

FIRST DAY - Saturday, June 20. Lancaster to Gettysburg, to Frederick, Md., to Harpers Ferry, W. Va., to Winchester, Va., down Shenandoah Valley, Roanoke to Galax, Va., south to Blue Ridge Parkway, entered North Carolina, night 33 miles into North Carolina on Parkway.

"Shoot, if you must, this old gray head,
But spare your country's flag," she said.
House and museum of Barbara Frietchie in Frederick, Md.
Highway bridge across Potomac River close to Harpers Ferry, where Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia come together.

blocks.text:
Although the main road now bypasses Harpers Ferry,
we decide to visit the town which is in a state of slow decay.
Thomas Jefferson remarked the view from the hilltop was worth a trip across the Atlantic.
On October 16, 1859, John Brown and 22 followers marched into Harpers Ferry
and took possession of the old Government armory as the first move in an insurrection aimed at freeing the slaves.
Brown and his followers were later subdued by Government troops led by Lt. Col.
Robert E. Lee. Subsequently Brown was tried and hanged as a traitor. His name became a symbol of militant resistance to slavery.
Above is seen the rebuilt fort of John Brown on the campus of Storer College for Negroes.
An early morning calling on the Vitals, former Lancastrians, who live near Strasburg, Va., within sight of the Massanutten Mountains.
Through a rich countrystyside,, with many apple orchards, to Winches-ter, Va., , strategically located at the head of the Shenandoah Valley.

blocks.text: Lexington, Va., in the Shenandoah Valley, contains two of the South's greatest shrines, the graves of Robert E. Lee and "Stonewall" Jackson. The town was founded about the time of the Revolutionary War by Scotch-Irish from Pennsylvania.
The Lee Memorial Chapel on the campus of Washington and Lee University where Lee served as president after the Civil War to the time of his death.

Interior of the Lee Chapel with recumbent statue of Lee by Valentine. In crypt are buried Lee and members of his family. These pictures by available light prove efficacy of new f/1.5 lens on Contax camera.
Shaded grounds and main buildings of Washington and Lee University. Virginia Military Institute is also located at north end off town.
The grave of "Stonewall" Jackson at southern edge of the town.

blocks.text: In the extreme southern part of Virginia, due south from Galax, we enter the Blue Ridge Parkway.
Far down the Shenandoah Valley as we near Roanoke.
A mile or two on the Parkway and we are in North Carolina.
First night spent at this new motel only a block from the Parkway.

SECOND DAY — Sunday, June 21. Blue Ridge Parkway in North Carolina, to top of Mt. Mitchell, to Asheville, to Cherokee, through Nantahala Gorge, into Tennessee almost to Cleveland. 7:45 A.M. to 9:45 P.M. M. 319 miles — total 757 miles.
A cloud, lower than we are, hovers over a distant valley.

blocks.text: Scenes on the Blue Ridge Parkway, an example of outstanding road construction, for the Parkway literally rides the backbone of the southern highlands. It is bright and clear on the top of the mountains, but the valleys are generally hazy making it difficult to photograph distant views.

blocks.text: Right - Here the road is cut from solid rock, with a steep drop over the side.

Two views of Grandfather Mountain (5,835'), near Blowing Rock, a resort town, one of the oldest mountains of the Appalachians. The road across the mountain is a constant succession of sharp curves, known as the Black Bear Trail (U. S. 221).

blocks.text: A dirt road leads several miles from the Park-way to the entrance of a trail, cut through the mountain fastness, to Linville Falls. We spend about an hour visiting only the upper falls, although the lower falls are probably the more interesting. It is a hot day and we return to the car wet from perspiration.
The road from Marion, N. C. twists and climbs up Buck Creek Gap to bisect the Parkway.

blocks.text: Approaching the Black Mountains, one of the largest mountain masses in the east. Extending eleven miles from north to south, there are fifteen peaks over 6,000 feet in elevation. One of these peaks, Mt. Mitchell, elevation 6,684 feet, is the highest moun-tain of the Appalachians as well as the highest peak east of the Mississippi River.

A spur road turns sharply right from the Parkway which we follow for approximately five miles to the parking area at the base of Mt. Mitchell. This road up the Black Mountains is steep but it has a good hard surface. From the parking area there is a foot trail of 285 yards to the stone tower on Mt.
Sandwiches and "pop" at this store maintained by the Park Commission. Prices are reasonable.
Climbing the Black Mountaintains to Mt. Mitchell.

blocks.text: After descending from Mt. Mitchell, we travel the Parkway southward once again heading for Asheville.
Craggy Gardens where rhododendron covers a whole mountain top.
From Asheville, N. C. (3:00 P. M.), we head east over Socco Gap to Cherokee, in the Indian Reservation at the edge of the Great Smoky Mountain National Park.
A tunnel through the mountains expedites our descent from the Parkway.
The children have a field day at Cherokee seek-ing Indian bracelets and jewelry from the many shops with curios on display.

blocks.text: Gordon photographs a Cherokee Indian in full cap and feathers; after which, to Kathy's complete surprise, the Indian places the headdress on her head for a picture.
Kathy tests the sharp teeth of a stuffed bear on the main street of Cherokee.

An extremely heavy rain storm just before we are ready to leave Cherokee causes us to alter our proposed trip over the Great Smokies and to head instead southwest through Nantahala Gorge. Rain, with a splattering of hail, follows us through the Gorge.

Murphy, a singularly unattractive town in the south-western corner of North Carolina, is in a marble quarrying region and boasts an all marble courthouse. Here we join U. S. 64, which we follow all the way into Oklahoma.

blocks.text: It is almost dark when we enter the man-made desert of southeastern Tennessee near Made town, where copper fumes from smelting operations have killed nearly all vegetation for a dozen miles causing widespread erosion. We have dinner at the aptly-named "Sahara" restaurant; then in complete darkness, accompanied by thunder and lightning, followed by rain, we drive a narrow, twisting road along the shore of a deep lake formed by one of the Government dams. We are glad indeed to locate a motel a few miles from Cleveland where we secure two rooms. After the others have gone to bed, Gordon takes a picture of himself in a mirror on the wall at 1/2 sec., f/1/5.
THIRD DAY — Monday, June 22. Cleveland, Tenn. to Chattanooga, southern Tennessee to Memphis, across Mississippi River into Arkansas as far as Clarksville.

On previous trips we had the impression Rock City, atop Lookout Mountain at Chattanooga, was advertised on half the barns in Dixie; now we find their advertising genius has located another medium - birdhouses.

We have dinner at the aptly-named "Sahara" restaurant; then in complete darkness, accompanied by thunder and lightning, followed by rain, we drive a narrow, twisting road along the shore of a deep lake formed by one of the Government dams. We are glad indeed to locate a motel a few miles from Cleveland where we secure two rooms. After the others have gone to bed, Gordon takes a picture of himself in a mirror on the wall at 1/2 sec., f/1/5.

THIRD DAY — Monday, June 22. Cleveland, Tenn. to Chattanooga, southern Tennessee to Memphis, across Mississippi River into Arkansas as far as Clarksville.

On previous trips we had the impression Rock City, atop Lookout Mountain at Chattanooga, was advertised on half the barns in Dixie; now we find their advertising genius has located another medium - birdhouses.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY — Wednesday, June 24. Ponca City, Okla., to Enid for National Convention of American Business Clubs. 11:00 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. 80 miles - total 1750 miles.

A late, leisurely breakfast at the Pioneer Grill in Ponca City before we leave for Enid.
Enid.
A modern oil pumper in a land made rich by this "black gold".

Ponca City to Enid...a section of Oklahoma known as "The Cherokee Strip". We drive for miles and miles past wheat fields which have already been harvest-ed. Every small town and cross roads has its grain elevators. An old gas station attendant, who declared he had been in Oklahoma since he was thirteen, reported he has never seen it so dry. Frequently, we see twirling winds carrying clouds of dust across the plains. The wind blows all the time.

We enter Enid in the early afternoon. It is so hot that the frames of Gordon's glasses feel uncomfortable against his face. When we unload our bags at the hotel, the wind is so strong it blows Kitty's heavy suitcase off the curb.
Enid, with a population of 360,000, is in the center of the state's wheat producing area. There are a number of enormous grain elevators in the city.

blocks.text: SIXTH DAY — Thursday, June 25; SEVENTH DAY, Friday, June 26; EIGHTH DAY, Saturday, June 27. In Enid, Okla. attending National Convention, American Business Clubs.
We secure a large room at the Oxford Hotel for the duration of the Convention. Reservations were made late due to uncertainty as to whether or not the children would accompany us.
The registration desk at the Youngblood Hotel, headquarters for the Convention. Almost 600 delegates and their families are in attendance, the largest register-ation in the history of ABC.
The Huntington, W. Va. delegation causes a sensation when both men and women arrive dressed as jailbirds to boost the candidacy of Jess Colbert for national president.

The slogan of advance publicity for the Convention has been: "Let's Meet at the Teepee in '53". We find a teepee housing a whole family of Indians erected in the lobby of the Youngblood Hotel. The Indian family remains there for the duration of the Convention. Cindy has her picture taken with the father (who happens to be a college graduate) and several of the children.

blocks.text: Thirty three miles west of Enid we cross the Cimarron River and find it completely dry. Ninety five percent of the rivers we cross in the southwest are in the same condition. This is the greatest drought in the history of the region. In some sections of southwest Texas there has been no rain for almost three years. Fields are reverting to dust bowls; cattle are dying by the thousands. Before we return home, we learn from the car radio that Congress has appropriated millions of dollars for relief.
The blowing prairies of western Oklahoma where the road stretches for mile after mile ahead of us and there are few signs of habitation.

Thirty three miles west of Enid we cross the Cimarron River and find it completely dry. Ninety five percent of the rivers we cross in the southwest are in the same condition. This is the greatest drought in the history of the region. In some sections of southwest Texas there has been no rain for almost three years. Fields are reverting to dust bowls; cattle are dying by the thousands. Before we return home, we learn from the car radio that Congress has appropriated millions of dollars for relief.

The blowing prairies of western Oklahoma where the road stretches for mile after mile ahead of us and there are few signs of habitation.

A ranch in the prairies of western Oklahoma. A ranchin n thinee praifairiiriririfees es cs oof westerntern Oklahalallahahohohomma..

blocks.text: Across the long bridge over the Canadian River (dry) and enter the small town of Canadian in eastern Panhandle section of Texas. This is a center for wheat and cattle.

We see our first flat top hill mountains, so characteristic of the southwest. We are near Pampa,
named for the resemblance of the neighboring prairies to the Argentina pampas. At Pampa oil wells stretch far on all sides.
Some of the land displays rough, eroded areas, known as "breaks".

We continue on through Amarillo, metroplis of the prairie region which has grown into a modern city in fifty years...and west across the Panhandle to the New Mexico line. This is a region of oil, cattle and grain.

blocks.text: Shortly after five o'clock we enter New Mexico after first having filled the gas tank at Texas prices.
The character of the land changes almost immediately. We are entering higher country and rough outcroppings of rock begin to appear. This is apparently cattle land, but it is semi-desert.

San Jon (left), the first small town in New Mexico makes its bid to keep the tourists' gasoline business at home. The elevation, as the result of a gradual, imperceptible rise from the east of several hundred miles, is now approximately 4,000 feet.

Tucumcari Mountain, named according to legend for the daughter of an Apache chief who lived there, over-looks the town of the same name. To look at Conchas Dam and Reservoir will provide water for 45,000 acres of irrigated land which is now almost wholly unproductive.

blocks.text:
Darkness has almost fallen when we stop at Lake View Motel at the edge of Santa Rosa. Mountain time, three hours behind our Eastern Daylight time, prevails.
Gordon resets his watch. After a light supper, the children make friends with the motel owner's cat. We are asked to use no more water than is necessary.

blocks.text: TENTH DAY - Monday, June 29. Santa Rosa to Santa Fe, northwest into Colorado at Pagosa Springs, through Durango to entrance Mesa Verde National Park in south-west corner of Colorado. 6:30 A. M. to 5:00 P. M. 365 miles - total 2548 miles.
At Clines Corners (only a crossroads with a store) we turn north for Santa Fe. The land continues to rise and we see the first signs of snow on the mountains (not perceptible on the picture.)

Perhaps ten miles south of Santa Fe
we cross the route of Coronado,
first white man to explore this region, as he led his army in search of gold and silver.

blocks.text: Left - Every other tourist seems to have a water bag slung over the front bumper of his car as a precaution for desert travel, so we decide we should have one too. Cost $1.50. It promptly begins to leak and requires constant filling. It is never needed.
The Palace of Governors, erected in 1609, was for 300 years the seat of government...is the oldest government building in the United States. It now houses the Museum of New Mexico.
Friendly, bashful Indian children sit within the shade of the portico.

blocks.text: The pattern of adobe construction is carried out in Santa Fe to a remarkable degree. Public buildings, homes and business places follow this type of construction. As a result, the city blends so completely with the surrounding terrain that you are actually uponing terrain that you are currently uponing this city of 30,000 people before you realize its presence.
U. S. Post Office.
Art Museum.
Presbyterian Church.

blocks.text: A quick stop for gas in Pagosa Springs... then a fast drive of 100 miles in slightly more than two hours in the hopes of reaching Mesa Verde Park Head-quarters to secure mail from home... but we arrive too late for mail this day. En route, we pause long enough to take a picture of this chimney rock.

ELEVENTH DAY — Tuesday, June 30. Visited Mesa Verde National Park, to Cortez, south again into New Mexico to Gallup, west into Arizona, Painted Desert, Petrified Forest National Monument, to Joseph City, Arizona. 7:00 A. M. to 7:50 P. M. 324 miles — total 2872 miles.

Entrance to Mesa Verde - the green tableland - in the extreme southwestern corner of Colorado. On this forested, flat-topped mountain overlooking Arizona, New Mexico and Utah are found the finest prehistoric Indian cliff dwellings in this country. Here amidst 50,000 acres of canyons and mesa are the excavated ruins and cliff dwellings of ancient Indians who built a culture long since vanished.

blocks.text:
The curious walled structure on the mesa,
at the head of a deep canyon, known as
the Sun Temple. The Temple was never com-
pleted, but it is believed to have been
built to placate the Sun God and to bring
an end to the protracted drought, which
in the end caused the inhabitants of the
mesa to disappear without trace.

UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR NATIONAL PARK SERVICE
MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK 15-DAY AUTOMOBILE PERMIT
THIS PERMIT EXPIRES (May 4) 1953

Another of the cliff dwellings where the Indians are believed to have lived until about 1,300 A.D. when they disappeared completely.

A view southward through one of the many sheer-walled canyons that cut into Mesa Verde's south side.

blocks.text: After descending from Mesa Verde, we travel westward for perhaps ten miles for a late breakfast in Cortez, Colorado. Southwest from here is the only point in the United States where four states meet, namely, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona and Utah. The desert area to the west is one of the wildest, inaccessible regions in the country. We had hoped to see Monument Valley, but decide against it when we learn the condition of the roads is such a set of tires can be ruined in less than a day's travel. The discovery of oil and uranium gives promise of future development.
Beyond the mountains to the west there are only desert, a few Indians, and virtually no roads.
Two horses and a colt roam the desert far from any sign of habitation.
Along the west face of Mesa Verde as we head due south for Gallup, a distance of 135 miles from Cortez.

blocks.text: Gordon tests the sun-drenched earth which is cracked open from the heat.

Welcome to New Mexico,
The Land of Enchantment.

We re-enter New Mexico and the Navajo Indian Reservation – largest in the country - where some 25,000 Navajos eke out a precarious existance in this forbidding land by tending sheep, weaving colorful rugs, and making silver jewelry. At one lonely trading post, an Indian necklace was priced at $195.00.

blocks.text: The Navajos live in “hogans”, mound-shaped houses of logs covered with a mud and grass roof, and without any shade whatever to protect them from the blazing sun.
Far in the distance the horizon is blotted out by a dust storm, which we pass through with lights on while sagebrush flies in every direction.

SHIPROCK
The large white monolith which stands on the beach here was formed by erosion. The first settlers in this area called it Ship Rock, because of its resemblance to a ship's hull and mast.
It is estimated that the rock has been standing for over 10 million years. It consists mainly of sandstone from an ancient sea bed.
Shiprock, a landmark for both Indians and Whites, rears 1,700 feet above the Navajo plains...is the gateway to Rattlesnake and other oil regions.

blocks.text: HOT DOGS HAMBURGER COFFEE
Kitty and Nancy sit on chunks of petrified tree trunks to survey the Painted Desert.

At the edge of the Painted Desert, a 300-mile stretch of land tinted shades of orange, blue, red, yellow and brown by iron and other minerals in the soil. A dark cloud overhead keeps us from getting the full effect of the sun on the soil.
It's getting late, but we decide to make a quick run through the Petrified Forest before seeking a motel for the night.

blocks.text: Within the Petrified Forest National Monument area, Newspaper Rock is inscribed with ancient Indian picture writings (petroglyphs) which have never been deciphered.
In some past geologic era these huge boulders must have been tossed about like matchsticks.

blocks.text: The chief feature of the Monument is the largest and most colorful collection of petrified wood in the world. Petrified log chunks are strewn about, many of them as colorful as gems. The theory is that these chunks were a part of a living for- est 170 million years ago, that the trunks were transported by floods from further north to this region where they became waterlogged and were buried beneath sand and shale which excluded oxygen, thus preventing rotting. Petrification followed with the formation of carnelian, agate, jasper, onyx, and opal. In recent times, erosion laid bare the petrified specimens. Note agate bridge at right.

blocks.text: Everything filled as we pass through Holbrook but we manage to secure excellent accommodations at Pacific Motel in Joseph City at nightfall. A late supper at a restaurant across the street. The children appear wide awake after a hard day's travel, much of it through desert heat.
